Why can phenol not be converted to phenyl chloride using PCl5 or SOCl2 under normal conditions, unlike alcohols?
options: \text{C-O bond in phenol has partial double bond character due to resonance with ring}
\text{Phenol is a liquid and cannot react with solid PCl}_5
\text{The OH group in phenol is too acidic to be replaced}
\text{Phenyl carbocation is too stable to form}
answer: \text{C-O bond in phenol has partial double bond character due to resonance with ring}
tip: Exactly analogous to vinyl chloride being unreactive. The lone pair on O delocalises into the ring → C-O gets partial double bond character → very hard to break. This is why phenol needs special conditions (e.g., POCl3 + pyridine) to give chlorobenzene.

options: \text{Tertiary alkyl halides undergo elimination (E2) with alkoxide instead of SN2 substitution}
\text{Tertiary alkyl halides are too stable to react}
\text{Alkoxide is too weak a nucleophile for tertiary halides}

options: \text{Increases acidity by stabilising phenoxide ion further through resonance}

options: \text{Phenol reacts as sodium phenoxide (PhO}^-\text{Na}^+\text{), not free phenol; phenoxide is a better nucleophile than CO}_2\text{ is electrophile at STP}
\text{CO}_2\text{ is a weaker electrophile than PhO}^-\text{ is nucleophile at all conditions}
\text{Phenol is a weaker acid than H}_2\text{CO}_3\text{ at high temperature}
\text{High pressure is needed only to dissolve CO}_2\text{, not for the reaction}
answer: \text{Phenol reacts as sodium phenoxide (PhO}^-\text{Na}^+\text{), not free phenol; phenoxide is a better nucleophile than CO}_2\text{ is electrophile at STP}
tip: The apparent contradiction: phenol is a weaker acid than H2CO3, yet PhONa + CO2 + H2O → PhOH + NaHCO3 (phenol displaced). This is because the Kolbe reaction uses PhO-Na+, not free PhOH. Sodium phenoxide (a strong nucleophile) attacks CO2 at high pressure. The product salicylate is then acidified to give salicylic acid.

Cleavage of methyl tert-butyl ether (CH3-O-C(CH3)3) with HI proceeds via SN1 or SN2? Which bond breaks and what are the products?
options: \text{SN1: tert-butyl C-O breaks; products are tert-butyl iodide + methanol}
\text{SN2: methyl C-O breaks; products are methyl iodide + tert-butanol}
\text{SN2: tert-butyl C-O breaks; products are tert-butyl iodide + methanol}
\text{SN1: methyl C-O breaks; products are methyl iodide + tert-butanol}
answer: \text{SN1: tert-butyl C-O breaks; products are tert-butyl iodide + methanol}
tip: Ether cleavage rule: the more substituted C-O bond breaks. 3° carbocation forms easily (SN1) → I- attacks → tert-BuI + CH3OH. If both groups were primary, SN2 would operate and the less hindered C-O would break.

question: Glycerol reacts with oxalic acid on heating to give acrolein via:

Hydroboration-oxidation gives anti-Markovnikov alcohol while acid-catalysed hydration gives Markovnikov alcohol from the same alkene. With 3,3-dimethylbut-1-ene, acid-catalysed hydration gives a rearranged product (2,3-dimethylbutan-2-ol) but hydroboration-oxidation gives the unrearranged product (3,3-dimethylbutan-1-ol). This is because:
options: \text{Hydroboration has no carbocation intermediate — BH}_3\text{ adds as a concerted syn process; no 1,2-shift possible}
\text{Hydroboration proceeds via a carbocation but the boron blocks rearrangement}
\text{Acid hydration also gives no rearrangement; the question premise is incorrect}
\text{Both proceed via carbocations, but hydroboration uses a bulkier borane that prevents shift}
answer: \text{Hydroboration has no carbocation intermediate — BH}_3\text{ adds as a concerted syn process; no 1,2-shift possible}
tip: This is the core reason hydroboration-oxidation is superior for sensitive substrates. Acid hydration: forms carbocation → 1,2-hydride or methyl shift → rearranged product. Hydroboration: four-membered cyclic transition state, concerted, no ionic intermediate → absolutely no rearrangement.
